snippet: Starting sometime in the next few months, California and Oregon will allow women to get a prescription directly from a pharmacist, a move that advocates hope becomes a national model.
abstract: California and Oregon move to allow pharmacists to provide contraceptives to women without doctor's prescription; measure is seen by bipartisan supporters as step toward goal of reducing unintended pregnancies, especially among low-income women, and hopes are that more states will adopt such laws.

byline.original: By PAM BELLUCK and SABRINA TAVERNISE

lead_paragraph: Starting sometime in the next few months, California and Oregon will allow women to get a prescription directly from a pharmacist, a move that advocates hope becomes a national model.

headline.main: States Lead Effort to Let Pharmacists Prescribe Birth Control
headline.print_headline: California and Oregon Lead Effort to Let Pharmacists Prescribe Birth Control

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
